{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3618668,"name":"Carter Eilert","username":"carterc13","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/e95f7d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-09T22:35:05.272Z","cooked":"

Hey CD, I had a few questions about elevators and motor controllers. This year we had an elevator that is belt-driven with 2 mechanically linked Kraken X60s on a 6:1 gear ratio. We ran it with a goal on the profiled PID and elevator feedforward controllers built into WPILib. Our elevator would occasionally get a little bit ahead of its setpoint and try to go back down, thus reducing its velocity. Then after a moment, it would be significantly behind the setpoint, which makes it jerk back up very quickly, and over time, the belts wear and eventually snap. I’ve tried tuning it the way CTRE and WPILib say in their docs with no luck. Is this a tuning issue? Is there another method that is more efficient and reliable? Also, for motor controllers, if we use a position/velocity voltage for TalonFX, does the PID run on the motor controller so loop overruns don’t affect it? Thanks a lot!

If your issue is sudden jerks wearing down the belt you could try a slew rate limiter to limit the acceleration.

carterc13:

Is this a tuning issue?

Yes. How did you initially calculate the feedforward gains?

Do you have logs that show the profile set point and the actual position of the elevator?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-05-09T22:53:45.530Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":218,"readers_count":217,"score":63.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":501499,"topic_slug":"elevator-motor-controller","display_username":"Tim Winters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19820,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"78 AIR Strike Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-motor-controller/501499/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3618697,"name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","username":"Knufire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-09T23:14:22.267Z","cooked":"

I think the proper solution here would be to use Motion Magic so you can also apply an acceleration cap that isn’t fighting against your controller. We had a somewhat similar issue this year, where raw PID control would jerk the elevator around hard enough to skip the chain, but there was no issues once a motion profile was added in.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-05-09T23:14:22.267Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":188,"readers_count":187,"score":87.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":501499,"topic_slug":"elevator-motor-controller","display_username":"Rahul Yarlagadda","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51417,"username":"CuteRedpandas","name":"Jared Van Horn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cuteredpandas/{size}/243322_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7457 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-motor-controller/501499/4","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3618707,"name":"Carter Eilert","username":"carterc13","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/e95f7d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-09T23:21:15.990Z","cooked":"

KG is the average of the voltage that made the elevator move up slowly and that made it move down slowly. KS is the voltage making it go up minus the voltage making it go down, all devided by 2. We then tuned kA and kV to the slope of the line and added some P for correction. It might take me a while to get logs as I don’t have easy acess to them right now. We also tested only using P and D but quickly abandoned it since it only made it worse.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-05-09T23:24:16.882Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":161,"readers_count":160,"score":32.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":501499,"topic_slug":"elevator-motor-controller","display_username":"Carter Eilert","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":19820,"username":"ArchdukeTim","name":"Tim Winters","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/archduketim/{size}/256125_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69500,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1710 Mech, Programming"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-motor-controller/501499/5","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3619015,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-10T13:34:57.432Z","cooked":"

I second this approach; MotionMagic is the way to go. We used it this year and didn’t see any notable issues. MotionMagic runs on the motor controller rather than the robotic as well, helping your loop overrun issues.
Even with MotionMagic, however, you’ll still need solid PID tuning. Right now, the problem you’re describing sounds like an underdampened system, where too much control input is being supplied to the system.

In my opinion, there are two ways you could go about fixing this - because even with MotionMagic this will need to be fixed. The first method is dropping your kP value until your elevator becomes overdampened and either fails to reach setpoint or does so slowly. From there, start moving kP upwards so that you get the system faster, but if you see that jumpy behavior stop and reduce kP.
An alternative solution is to introduce kD gain to push back against when PID is moving too fast. But this is more error-prone because it requires messing around with two variables rather than just one.

One other “solution” is reducing the values for kV and kA. We had significant issues with our steer motors this year where seemingly little values of kV and kA caused massive jitter in reaching setpoint. We solved the problem by setting them to zero and just tuning kP. This makes the behavior of the system less dependent on so many variables, simplifying the tuning process. We ended with a much better result that noticeably improved driving. I’d try running only kP and seeing how bad that is.
